member.name: T:Aspose.Words.ImportFormatMode
member.summary: Specifies how formatting is merged when importing content from another document.

remarks.p: When you copy nodes from one document to another, this option specifies how formatting is resolved when both documents have a style with the same name, but different formatting.
The formatting is resolved as follows:

list.item: Built-in styles are matched using their locale independent style identifier. User defined styles are matched using case-sensitive style name.

If a matching style is not found in the destination document, the style (and all styles referenced by it) are copied into the destination document and the imported nodes are updated to reference the new style.
If a matching style already exists in the destination document, what happens depends on the importFormatMode parameter passed to Document.ImportNode as described below.

remarks.p: When using the UseDestinationStyles option, if a matching style already exists in the destination document, the style is not copied and the imported nodes are updated to reference the existing style.

The drawback of using UseDestinationStyles is that the imported text might look different in the destination document comparing to the source document. For example, the "Heading 1" style in the source document uses Arial 16pt font and the "Heading 1" style in the destination document uses Times New Roman 14pt font. When importing text of "Heading 1" style with no other direct formatting, it will appear as Times New Roman 14pt font in the destination document.

Using the KeepSourceFormatting option allows to make sure the imported text looks in the destination document exactly like it was in the source document. If a matching style already exists in the destination document, the source style is copied and given a unique name by appending a suffix number to it, for example "Normal_0" or "Heading 1_5".

The drawback of using KeepSourceFormatting is that if you perform several imports, you could end up with many styles in the destination document and that could make using consistent style formatting in Microsoft Word difficult for this document.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ImportFormatMode.UseDestinationStyles
member.summary: Use the destination document styles and copy new styles. This is the default option.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ImportFormatMode.KeepSourceFormatting
member.summary: Copy all required styles to the destination document, generate unique style names if needed.

member.name: T:Aspose.Layout.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: The Aspose.Layout namespace contains classes of the layout model. These are classes used internally by the Aspose.Editor and Aspose.Words products.

summary.p: The Aspose.Words namespace provides classes for generating, converting, modifying, rendering and printing Microsoft Word documents without utilizing Microsoft Word.
Aspose.Words is written completely in C#, CLS compliant and contains only safe managed code. Microsoft Word is not required in order to use Aspose.Words.

The classes in the Aspose.Words namespace borrow best practices from two well-known frameworks: Microsoft Word Automation and System.Xml. A document in Aspose.Words is represented by a tree of nodes, much like in XML DOM. Where possible, class, method and property names match those found in Microsoft Word Automation.
The main classes in this namespace are:

list.item: is the main class of the object model that represents a Microsoft Word document.
provides an easy way to insert content and formatting into a document.
is the base class for all nodes in the document.
is the base class for all nodes of the document that can contain other nodes, for example , and .

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.ParagraphFormat.FirstLineIndent
member.summary: Gets or sets the value (in points) for a first line or hanging indent. Use a positive value to set a first-line indent, and use a negative value to set a hanging indent.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.ParagraphFormat.SpaceBeforeAuto
member.summary: True if the amount of spacing before the paragraph is set automatically.

remarks.p: When set to true, overrides the effect of .
When you set paragraph Space Before and Space After to Auto, Microsoft Word adds 14 points spacing between paragraphs automatically according to the following rules:

list.item: Normally, spacing is added after all paragraphs.
In a bulleted or numbered list, spacing is added only after the last item in the list. Spacing is not added between the list items.
In a nested bulleted or numbered list spacing is not added.
Spacing is normally added after a table.
Spacing is not added after a table if it is the last block in a table cell.
Spacing is not added after the last paragraph in a table cell.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.ParagraphFormat.SpaceAfterAuto
member.summary: True if the amount of spacing after the paragraph is set automatically.

remarks.p: When set to true, overrides the effect of .
When you set paragraph Space Before and Space After to Auto, Microsoft Word adds 14 points spacing between paragraphs automatically according to the following rules:

list.item: Normally, spacing is added after all paragraphs.
In a bulleted or numbered list, spacing is added only after the last item in the list. Spacing is not added between the list items.
In a nested bulleted or numbered list spacing is not added.
Spacing is normally added after a table.
Spacing is not added after a table if it is the last block in a table cell.
Spacing is not added after the last paragraph in a table cell.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.ParagraphFormat.SpaceBefore
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of spacing (in points) before the paragraph.

remarks.p: Has no effect when is true.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.ParagraphFormat.SpaceAfter

remarks.p: Has no effect when is true.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.ParagraphFormat.LineSpacing
member.summary: Gets or sets the line spacing (in points) for the paragraph.

remarks.p: When LineSpacingRule property is set to AtLeast, the line spacing can be greater than or equal to, but never less than the specified LineSpacing value.
When LineSpacingRule propert is set to Exactly, the line spacing never changes from the specified LineSpacing value, even if a larger font is used within the paragraph.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.ListFormat
member.summary: Allows to control what list formatting is applied to a paragraph.

remarks.p: A paragraph in a Microsoft Word document can be bulleted or numbered. When a paragraph is bulleted or numbered, it is said that list formatting is applied to the paragraph.

You do not create objects of the class directly. You access as a property of another object that can have list formatting associated with it. At the moment the objects that can have list formatting are: , and .
of a specifies what list formatting and list level is applied to that particular paragraph.
of a (applicable to paragraph styles only) allows to specify what list formatting and list level is applied to all paragraphs of that particular style.
of a provides access to the list formatting at the current cursor position inside the .
The list formatting itself is stored inside a object that is stored separately from the paragraphs. The list objects are stored inside a collection. There is a single collection per .

The paragraphs do not physically belong to a list. The paragraphs just reference a particular list object via the property and a particular level in the list via the property. By setting these two properties you control what bullets and numbering is applied to a paragraph.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.ListFormat.ApplyBulletDefault
member.summary: Starts a new default bulleted list and applies it to the paragraph.

remarks.p: This is a shorctut method that creates a new list using the default bulleted template, applies it to the paragraph and selects the 1st list level.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.ListFormat.ApplyNumberDefault
member.summary: Starts a new default numbered list and applies it to the paragraph.

remarks.p: This is a shorctut method that creates a new list using the default numbered template, applies it to the paragraph and selects the 1st list level.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.ListFormat.RemoveNumbers
member.summary: Removes numbers or bullets from the current paragraph and sets list level to zero.

remarks.p: Calling this method is equivalent to setting the property to null.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.ListFormat.ListIndent
member.summary: Increases the list level of the current paragraph by one level.

remarks.p: This method changes the list level and applies formatting properties of the new level.
In Word documents, lists may consist of up to nine levels. List formatting for each level specifies what bullet or number is used, left indent, space between the bullet and text etc.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.ListFormat.ListOutdent
member.summary: Decreases the list level of the current paragraph by one level.

remarks.p: This method changes the list level and applies formatting properties of the new level.
In Word documents, lists may consist of up to nine levels. List formatting for each level specifies what bullet or number is used, left indent, space between the bullet and text etc.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.ListFormat.ListLevelNumber
member.summary: Gets or sets the list level number (0 to 8) for the paragraph.

remarks.p: In Word documents, lists may consist of 1 or 9 levels, numbered 0 to 8.
Has effect only when the property is set to reference a valid list.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.ListFormat.IsListItem
member.summary: True when the paragraph has bulleted or numbered formatting applied to it.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.ListFormat.List
member.summary: Gets or sets the list this paragraph is a member of.

remarks.p: The list that is being assigned to this property must belong to the current document.
The list that is being assigned to this property must not be a list style definition.
Setting this property to null removes bullets and numbering from the paragraph and sets the list level number to zero. Setting this property to null is equivalent to calling .

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.ListFormat.ListLevel
member.summary: Returns the list level formatting plus any formatting overrides applied to the current paragraph.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions
member.summary: Provides various options that control how a document is saved.

remarks.p: The objectis a set of options that allow you to control how Aspose.Words saves a . is not persisted with the .

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.ExportPrettyFormat
member.summary: When true, pretty formats output where applicable. Default value is false.

remarks.p: Set to true to make HTML, MHTML, EPUB, WordML, RTF, DOCX and ODT output human readable. Useful for testing or debugging.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.ExportImagesFolder
member.summary: Specifies the physical folder where images are saved when saving a document to a stream in the HTML or Aspose.Pdf XML format.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportImagesFolder
member.summary: Specifies the physical folder where images are saved when exporting a document to HTML format. Default is an empty string.

remarks.p: When you save a in HTML format, Aspose.Words needs to save all images embedded in the document as standalone files. allows you to specify where the images will be saved and allows to specify how the image URIs will be constructed.
If you save a document into a file and provide a file name, Aspose.Words, by default, saves the images in the same folder where the document file is saved. Use to override this behavior.

If you save a document into a stream, Aspose.Words does not have a folder where to save the images, but still needs to save the images somewhere. In this case, you need to specify an accessible folder in the property or provide custom streams via the event handler.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportImagesFolderAlias
member.summary: Specifies the name of the folder used to construct image URIs written into an HTML document. Default is an empty string.

remarks.p: When you save a in HTML format, Aspose.Words needs to save all images embedded in the document as standalone files. allows you to specify where the images will be saved and allows to specify how the image URIs will be constructed.
If is not an empty string, then the image URI written to HTML will be HtmlExportImagesFolderAlias + <image file name>.
If is an empty string, then the image URI written to HTML will be HtmlExportImagesFolder + <image file name>.
If is set to '.' (dot), then the image file name will be written to HTML without path regardless of other options.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportCssStyleSheetFileName
member.summary: Specifies the name of the Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) file written with the exported document. Default is an empty string.

remarks.p: Note, this property has effect only when saving a in HTML format and external CSS style sheet is requested using .
remarks.para: If you don't specify a value for this property, then the style sheet file will have the same name as the HTML document name, but with a ".css" extension.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportTextInputFormFieldAsText
member.summary: Specifies how to export Word text input form fields to HTML. Default value is false.

remarks.p: When false, exports Word text input form fields as INPUT elements in HTML. When set to true, exports text input form fields as normal text.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportHeadersFooters
member.summary: Specifies whether to output headers and footers to HTML. Default value is true.

remarks.p: It is hard to meaningfully output headers and footers to HTML because HTML is not paginated. When this property is true, Aspose.Words exports only primary headers and footers at the beginning and end of each section. You can disable export of headers and footers altogether by setting this property to false.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportAllowNegativeLeftIndent
member.summary: Specifies whether negative left indent of paragraphs is normalized when exporting to HTML. Default value is false.

remarks.p: When negative left indent is not allowed, it is exported as zero left margin to HTML. When negative left indent is allowed, a paragraph might appear partially outside of the browser window.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportXhtmlTransitional
member.summary: When true, writes a DOCTYPE declaration in the document prior to the root element. Default value is false.

remarks.p: Aspose.Words always writes well formed HTML regardless of this setting.
When true, the beginning of the HTML output document will look like this:
remarks.code: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" standalone="no" ?> <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> <html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xml:lang="en" lang="en">
remarks.p: Aspose.Words aims to output XHTML according to the XHTML 1.0 Transitional specification, but the output will not always validate against the DTD. Some structures inside a Microsoft Word document are hard or impossible to map to a document that will validate against the XHTML schema. For example, XHTML does not allow nested lists (UL cannot be nested inside another UL element), but in Microsoft Word document multilevel lists occur quite often.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportDocumentProperties
member.summary: Specifies whether to export built-in and custom document properties to HTML. Default value is false.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportMetafileAsRaster
member.summary: Specifies whether to convert metafiles into raster images when exporting to HTML. Default value is true.

remarks.p: Metafiles are not natively displayed by HTML browsers. By default, Aspose.Words converts WMF and EMF images into PNG files when exporting to HTML. Setting this property to false causes metafiles to be exported to HTML without conversion.
Some image transforms, in particular image cropping, will not be applied to metafile images if this property is false.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportScaleImageToShapeSize
member.summary: Specifies whether images are scaled by Aspose.Words to the bounding shape size when exporting to HTML. Default value is true.

remarks.p: An image in a Microsoft Word document is a shape. The shape has a size and the image has its own size. The sizes are not directly linked. For example, the image can be 1024x786 pixels, but shape that displays this image can be 400x300 points.

In order to display an image in the browser, it must be scaled to the shape size. The property controls where the scaling of the image takes place: in Aspose.Words during export to HTML or in the browser when displaying the document.
When is true, the image is scaled by Aspose.Words using high quality scaling during export to HTML. When is false, the image is output with its original size and the browser has to scale it.

In general, browsers do quick and poor quality scaling. As a result, you will normally get better display quality in the browser and smaller file size when is true, but better printing quality and faster conversion when is false.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportImageResolution
member.summary: Specifies the output resolution for images when exporting to HTML. Default is 96 dpi.

remarks.para: This property has effect for raster images only when is true and it has effect for metafiles only when is true.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportMetafileResolution
member.summary: Specifies the resolution at which metafiles are converted to raster images when exporting to HTML. Default is 96 dpi.

remarks.p: Metafiles are not natively displayed by browsers and therefore Aspose.Words converts WMF and EMF images into PNG files when exporting to HTML. This setting specifies the resolution of the created PNG files. If the HTML file is intended to be viewed on the screen, the default setting will produce images of adequate quality and small size.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportCssStyleSheetType
member.summary: Specifies how CSS (Cascading Style Sheet) styles are exported to HTML.

remarks.p: The default value is .

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportPageSetup
member.summary: Specifies whether page setup is exported to HTML. Default is false.

remarks.p: Each in Aspose.Words document model provides page setup information via class. When you export a document to HTML format you might need to keep this information for further usage. In particular, page setup might be important for rendering to paged media (printing) or subsequent conversion to the native Microsoft Word file formats (DOCX, DOC, RTF, WML).
In most cases HTML is intended for viewing in browsers where pagination is not performed. So this feature is inactive by default.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportEncoding
member.summary: Specifies the encoding to use when exporting to HTML format. Default value is Encoding.UTF8.

member.name: E:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.HtmlExportImageSaving
member.summary: Allows to control how images are saved when a document is exported to HTML format. Occurs when an image is about to be saved.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.EpubExportNavigationMapLevel
member.summary: Specifies the maximum level of headings populated to the navigation map when exporting to IDPF EPUB format. Default value is 3.

remarks.p: Navigation map in IDPF EPUB format allows user agents to provide easy way of navigation through the document structure. Usually navigation points correspond to headings in the document. To populate headings up to level N assign this value to EpubExportNavigationMapLevel.

By default three levels of headings are populated: paragraphs of styles Heading 1, Heading 2 and Heading 3. You can set this property to a value from 1 to 9 to request corresponding maximum level. Setting it to zero will reduce navigation map to only one element - document root.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.PdfExportImagesFolder
member.summary: Specifies the physical folder where images are saved when exporting a document to Aspose.Pdf XML format. Default is an empty string.

remarks.p: When you save a in the Aspose.Pdf XML format, Aspose.Words needs to save all images embedded in the document as standalone files. allows you to specify where the images will be saved.
If you save a document into a file and provide a file name, Aspose.Words, by default, saves the images in the same folder where the document file is saved. Use to override this behavior.

If you save a document into a stream, Aspose.Words does not have a folder where to save the images, but still needs to save the images somewhere. In this case, you need to specify an accessible folder in the property or provide custom streams via the event handler.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.PdfExportBookmarkLevel
member.summary: Specifies whether bookmarks for heading paragraphs are created in a PDF file when exporting to Aspose.Pdf XML format.

remarks.p: PDF bookmarks, if used, are visible in the Bookmarks pane in the PDF viewer. PDF bookmarks allow quick navigation to specific places in a document.
By default, PdfExportBookmarkLevel is zero and PDF bookmarks are not created.
You can set PdfExportBookmarkLevel to a value from 1 to 9 to request PDF bookmarks created for paragraphs marked with styles Heading 1 to Heading 9 respectively.
For example, if you set PdfExportBookmarkLevel to 3, then all paragraphs with styles Heading 1, Heading 2 and Heading 3 will be marked as PDF bookmarks.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.PdfExportFormFieldsAsText
member.summary: Specifies how to export Word form fields to Aspose.Pdf XML format. Default value is true.

remarks.p: True to export Word form fields as normal text; false to export form fields as Adobe Acrobat Form Fields.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.PdfExportCheckBoxFontName
member.summary: Specifies the font to simulate check box form fields in Aspose.Pdf XML format. Default value is "Wingdings".

remarks.p: When is set to true form fields are exported to PDF as normal text. In Microsoft Word and Adobe Acrobat native check boxes look differently: crosses and ticks respectively. By default check box marks are simulated as ticks. You can change simulation options, in particular to make check boxes look as they appear in Microsoft Word document.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.PdfExportCheckBoxEmptySign
member.summary: Specifies the symbol to simulate unselected check box form fields in Aspose.Pdf XML format. Default value is '\xa8'.

remarks.p: When is set to true form fields are exported to PDF as normal text. In Microsoft Word and Adobe Acrobat native check boxes look differently: crosses and ticks respectively. By default check box marks are simulated as ticks. You can change simulation options, in particular to make check boxes look as they appear in Microsoft Word document.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.PdfExportCheckBoxSelectedSign
member.summary: Specifies the symbol to simulate selected check box form fields in Aspose.Pdf XML format. Default value is '\xfe'.

remarks.p: When is set to true form fields are exported to PDF as normal text. In Microsoft Word and Adobe Acrobat native check boxes look differently: crosses and ticks respectively. By default check box marks are simulated as ticks. You can change simulation options, in particular to make check boxes look as they appear in Microsoft Word document.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.PdfExportMetafileResolution
member.summary: Specifies resolution at which metafiles are converted to raster images when exporting to Aspose.Pdf XML format. Default is 300 dpi.

remarks.p: Aspose.Pdf converts metafiles to raster images when creating a PDF file. This setting specifies the resolution of the created raster images. Higher resolution will result in higher quality image when printing the PDF file or viewing at high zoom value, but it will also result in bigger PDF file size.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.PdfExportFloatingTables
member.summary: Specifies whether absolutely positioned tables are output as floating objects to PDF. Default is false.

remarks.p: Tables in Microsoft Word can be absolutely positioned. They should be normally output as floating objects to PDF but this conflicts with a functional restriction in Aspose.Pdf: it doesn't support text wrapping around floating objects. As in most cases output looks better without floating tables this feature is turned off by default.

member.name: E:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.PdfExportImageSaving
member.summary: Allows to control how images are saved when a document is exported to Aspose.Pdf XML. Occurs when an image is about to be saved.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.RtfExportCompactSize
member.summary: Specifies whether to generate compact size RTF documents. When this property is true, some RTF features intended for old readers are omitted. Default value is false.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.TxtExportHeadersFooters
member.summary: Specifies whether to output headers and footers when exporting in plain text format. Default value is true.

remarks.p: It is hard to meaningfully output headers and footers to plain text because it is not paginated. When this property is true, Aspose.Words exports only primary headers and footers at the beginning and end of each section. You can disable export of headers and footers altogether by setting this property to false.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.TxtExportEncoding
member.summary: Specifies the encoding to use when exporting in plain text format. Default value is Encoding.UTF8.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.TxtExportParagraphBreak
member.summary: Specifies the string to use as a paragraph break when exporting in plain text format.

remarks.p: The default value is .

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.SaveOptions.TxtExportTableLayout
member.summary: Specifies whether tables should preserve layout when exporting in plain text format. The default value is false.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.DocumentBuilder
member.summary: Provides methods to insert text, images and other content, specify font, paragraph and section formatting.

remarks.p: DocumentBuilder makes the process of building a Document easier. Document is a composite object consisting of a tree of nodes and while inserting content nodes directly into the tree is possible, it requires good understanding of the tree structure. DocumentBuilder is a "facade" for the complex structure of Document and allows to insert content and formatting quickly and easily.
Create a DocumentBuilder and associate it with a .

The DocumentBuilder has an internal cursor where the text will be inserted when you call , , and other methods. You can navigate the DocumentBuilder cursor to a different location in a document using various MoveToXXX methods.
Use the property to specify character formatting that will apply to all text inserted from the current position in the document onwards.
Use the property to specify paragraph formatting for the current and all paragraphs that will be inserted.
Use the property to specify page and section properties for the current section and all section that will be inserted.
Use the and properties to specify formatting properties for table cells and rows. User the and methods to build a table.
Note that Font, ParagraphFormat and PageSetup properties are updated whenever you navigate to a different place in the document to reflect formatting properties available at the new location.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.DocumentBuilder.MoveToBookmark(System.String)
member.summary: Moves the cursor to a bookmark.

remarks.p: Moves the cursor to a position just after the start of the bookmark with the specified name.
The comparison is not case-sensitive. If the bookmark was not found, false is returned and the cursor is not moved.
Inserting new text does not replace existing text of the bookmark.

Note that some bookmarks in the document are assigned to form fields. Moving to such a bookmark and inserting text there inserts the text into the form field code. Although this will not invalidate the form field, the inserted text will not be visible because it becomes part of the field code.

member.param: The name of the bookmark to move the cursor to.
member.returns: True if the bookmark was found; false otherwise.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.DocumentBuilder.MoveToBookmark(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves the cursor to a bookmark with greater precision.

remarks.p: Moves the cursor to a position before or after the bookmark start or end.
The comparison is not case-sensitive. If the bookmark was not found, false is returned and the cursor is not moved.

member.param: The name of the bookmark to move the cursor to.
When true, moves the cursor to the beginning of the bookmark. When false, moves the cursor to the end of the bookmark.
When true, moves the cursor to be after the bookmark start or end position. When false, moves the cursor to be before the bookmark start or end position.
member.returns: True if the bookmark was found; false otherwise.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.DocumentBuilder.MoveToParagraph(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Moves the cursor to a paragraph in the current section.

remarks.p: The navigation is performed inside the current story of the current section. That is, if you moved the cursor to the primary header of the first section, then paragraphIndex specified the index of the paragraph inside that header of that section.

When paragraphIndex is greater than or equal to 0, it specifies an index from the beginning of the section with 0 being the first paragraph. When paragraphIndex is less than 0, it specified an index from the end of the section with -1 being the last paragraph.

member.param: The index of the paragraph to move to.
The index of the character inside the paragraph. Currently can only specify 0 to move to the beginning of the paragraph or -1 to move to the end of the paragraph.

member.summary: Moves the cursor to a table cell in the current section.

remarks.p: The navigation is performed inside the current story of the current section.

For the index parameters, when index is greater than or equal to 0, it specifies an index from the beginning with 0 being the first element. When index is less than 0, it specified an index from the end with -1 being the last element.

member.param: The index of the table to move to.
The index of the row in the table.
The index of the column in the table.
The index of the character inside the cell. Currently can only specify 0 to move to the beginning of the cell or -1 to move to the end of the cell.

member.summary: Moves the cursor to an inline node or to the end of a paragraph.

remarks.p: When node is an inline-level node, the cursor is moved to this node and further content will be inserted before that node.
When node is a Paragraph, the cursor is moved to the end of the paragraph and further content will be inserted just before the paragraph break.

member.param: The node must be a paragraph or a direct child of a paragraph.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.DocumentBuilder.DeleteRow(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Deletes a row from a table.

remarks.p: If the cursor is inside the row that is being deleted, the cursor is moved out to the next row or to the next paragraph after the table.
If you delete a row from a table that contains only one row, the whole table is deleted.

For the index parameters, when index is greater than or equal to 0, it specifies an index from the beginning with 0 being the first element. When index is less than 0, it specified an index from the end with -1 being the last element.

member.param: The index of the table.
The index of the row in the table.
member.returns: The row node that was just removed.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.DocumentBuilder.InsertTableOfContents(System.String)
member.summary: Inserts a TOC (table of contents) field into the document.

remarks.p: This method inserts a TOC (table of contents) field into the document at the current position.

A table of contents in a Word document can be built in a number of ways and formatted using a variety of options. The way the table is built and displayed by Microsoft Word is controlled by the field switches.

The easiest way to specify the switches is to insert and configure a table of contents into a Word document using the Insert->Reference->Index and Tables menu, then switch display of field codes on to see the switches. You can press Alt+F9 in Microsoft Word to toggle display of field codes on or off.
For example, after creating a table of contents, the following field is inserted into the document: { TOC \o "1-3" \h \z \u }. You can copy \o "1-3" \h \z \u and use it as the switches parameter.
Note that InsertTableOfContents will only insert a TOC field, but will not actually build the table of contents. The table of contents is built by Microsoft Word when the field is updated.
If you insert a table of contents using this method and then open the file in Microsoft Word, you will not see the table of contents because the TOC field has not yet been updated.
In Microsoft Word, fields are not automatically updated when a document is opened, but you can update fields in a document at any time by pressing F9.

member.param: The TOC field switches.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.DocumentBuilder.InsertField(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Inserts a Word field into the document.

remarks.p: Fields in MS Word documents consist of a field code and a field result. The field code is like a formula and the field result is like the value that the formula produces. The field code may also contain field switches that are like additional instructions to perform a specific action.
You can switch between displaying field codes and results in your document in MS Word using the keyboard shortcut Alt+F9. Field codes appear between curly braces ( { } ).

To create fields using , you need to specify a field type, field code and field value. If you are not sure about particular field code syntax, create the field in MS Word first and switch to see its field code.

member.param: Field code to insert (without curly braces).
Field value to insert. Pass null for fields that do not have a value.
member.returns: A node that represents the beginning of the inserted field.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.DocumentBuilder.InsertHyperlink(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Inserts a hyperlink into the document.

remarks.p: Note that you need to specify font formatting for the hyperlink display text explicitly using the property.
This methods internally calls to insert an MS Word HYPERLINK field into the document.

member.param: Text of the link to be displayed in the document.
Link destination. Can be a url or a name of a bookmark inside the document. This method always adds apostrophes at the beginning and end of the url.
True if the previous parameter is a name of a bookmark inside the document; false is the previous parameter is a URL.
member.returns: A node that represents the beginning of the inserted field.

member.summary: Marks the current position in the document as a bookmark start.

remarks.p: Bookmarks in a document can overlap and span any range. To create a valid bookmark you need to call both and with the same bookmarkName parameter.
Badly formed bookmarks or bookmarks with duplicate names will be ignored when the document is saved.

member.param: Name of the bookmark.
member.returns: The bookmark start node that was just created.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.DocumentBuilder.EndBookmark(System.String)

remarks.p: Bookmarks in a document can overlap and span any range. To create a valid bookmark you need to call both and with the same bookmarkName parameter.
Badly formed bookmarks or bookmarks with duplicate names will be ignored when the document is saved.

member.param: Name of the bookmark.
member.returns: The bookmark end node that was just created.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.BookmarkStart
member.summary: Represents a start of a bookmark in a Word document.

remarks.p: A complete bookmark in a Word document consists of a and a matching with the same bookmark name.
and are just markers inside a document that specify where the bookmark starts and ends.
Use the class as a "facade" to work with a bookmark as a single object.
remarks.note: Currently bookmarks are supported only at the inline-level, that is inside , but bookmark start and bookmark end can be in different paragraphs.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Tables.RowCollection.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves a Row at the given index.

remarks.p: The index is zero-based.
Negative indexes are allowed and indicate access from the back of the collection. For example -1 means the last item, -2 means the second before last and so on.
If index is greater than or equal to the number of items in the list, this returns a null reference.
If index is negative and its absolute value is greater than the number of items in the list, this returns a null reference.

member.param: An index into the collection.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.Story
member.summary: Base class for elements that contain block-level nodes and .

remarks.p: Text of a Word document is said to consist of several stories. The main text is stored in the main text story represented by , each header and footer is stored in a separate story represented by .

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Story.Clone(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a duplicate of the node.

remarks.p: This method serves as a copy constructor for nodes. The cloned node has no parent, but belongs to the same document as the original node.
This method always performs a deep copy of the node. The isCloneChildren parameter specifies whether to perform copy all child nodes as well.

member.param: True to recursively clone the subtree under the specified node; false to clone only the node itself.
member.returns: The cloned node.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.Properties.BuiltInDocumentProperties
member.summary: A collection of built-in document properties.

remarks.p: Provides access to objects by their names (using an indexer) and via a set of typed properties that return values of appropriate types.
The names of the properties are case-insensitive.
The properties in the collection are sorted alphabetically by name.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Properties.BuiltInDocumentProperties.Item(System.String)
member.overloads: Returns a object.
member.summary: Returns a object by the name of the property.

remarks.p: The string names of the properties correspond to the names of the typed properties available from .

If you request a property that is not present in the document, but the name of the property is recognized as a valid built-in name, a new is created, added to the collection and returned. The newly created property is assigned a default value (empty string, zero, false or DateTime.MinValue depending on the type of the built-in property).
If you request a property that is not present in the document and the name is not recognized as a built-in name, a null is returned.

member.param: The case-insensitive name of the property to retrieve.

remarks.para: Use this property for informational purposes only because Microsoft Word does not always set this property. This property is available in DOC and OOXML documents only.
To protect or unprotect a document use the and methods.
Aspose.Words updates this property to a correct value before saving a document.

member.summary: Gets or sets the informational name of the document template.

Empty string means the document is attached to the Normal template.
To get or set the actual name of the attached template, use the property.

member.summary: Represents the version number of the application that created the document.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Properties.BuiltInDocumentProperties.Words
member.summary: Represents an estimate of the number of words in the document.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Properties.BuiltInDocumentProperties.HeadingPairs
member.summary: Specifies document headings and their names.

remarks.para: Every heading pair occupies two elements in this array.
The first element of the pair is a and specifies the heading name. The second element of the pair is an and specifies the count of document parts for this heading in the property.
The total sum of counts for all heading pairs in this property must be equal to the number of elements in the property.
remarks.p: Aspose.Words does not update this property.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Properties.BuiltInDocumentProperties.TitlesOfParts
member.summary: Each string in the array specifies the name of a part in the document.

remarks.p: Aspose.Words does not update this property.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MergeFieldEventArgs
member.summary: Provides data for the MergeField event.

remarks.p: The MergeField event occurs during mail merge when a simple mail merge field is encountered in the document. You can respond to this event to return text for the mail merge engine to insert into the document.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MergeFieldEventArgs.Text
member.summary: Gets or sets the text that will be inserted into the document for the current merge field.

remarks.p: When your event handler is called, this property is set to null.
If you leave Text as null, the mail merge engine will insert in place of the merge field.
If you set Text to any string (including empty), the string will be inserted into the document in place of the merge field.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.Drawing.ShapeType
member.summary: Specifies the type of shape in a Microsoft Word document.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Drawing.ShapeType.Image
member.summary: The shape is an image.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Drawing.ShapeType.TextBox
member.summary: The shape is a textbox. Note that shapes of many other types can also have text inside them too. A shape does not have to have this type to contain text.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Drawing.ShapeType.Group

summary.p: The shape is a group shape.

member.dev: In DOC file, shape group has shape type NonPrimitive, we don't want this in the model, so in the model it is our own constant.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Drawing.ShapeType.OleObject
member.summary:
The shape is an OLE object.
You cannot create shapes of this type in the document.
member.dev: In Microsoft Word, shapes that represent OLE objects have shape type picture, but in our model, they are distinguished into their own shape type.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Drawing.ShapeType.OleControl
member.summary:
The shape is an ActiveX control.
You cannot create shapes of this type in the document.
member.dev: In DOC and RTF, shapes that represent ActiveX controls have shape type picture. In WordML, ActiveX controls have their own shape type and so is in the model.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Drawing.ShapeType.NonPrimitive
member.summary:
A shape drawn by user and consisting of multiple segments and/or vertices (curve, freeform or scribble).
You cannot create shapes of this type in the document.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Drawing.ShapeType.CustomShape
member.summary:
This shape type seems to be set for shapes that are not part of the standard set of the auto shapes in Microsoft Word. For example, if you insert a new auto shape from ClipArt.
You cannot create shapes of this type in the document.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.Fonts.FontFamily
member.summary: Represents the font family.

remarks.para: A font family is a set of fonts having common stroke width and serif characteristics.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Fonts.FontFamily.Auto
member.summary: Specifies a generic family name. This name is used when information about a font does not exist or does not matter. The default font is used.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Fonts.FontFamily.Roman
member.summary: Specifies a proportional font with serifs. An example is Times New Roman.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Fonts.FontFamily.Swiss
member.summary: Specifies a proportional font without serifs. An example is Arial.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Fonts.FontFamily.Modern
member.summary: Specifies a monospace font with or without serifs. Monospace fonts are usually modern; examples include Pica, Elite, and Courier New.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Fonts.FontFamily.Script
member.summary: Specifies a font that is designed to look like handwriting; examples include Script and Cursive.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Fonts.FontFamily.Decorative
member.summary: Specifies a novelty font. An example is Old English.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.BorderCollection
member.summary: A collection of Border objects.
member.remarks: Different document elements have different borders. For example, ParagraphFormat has Bottom, Left, Right and Top borders. You can specify different formatting for each border independently or enumerate through all borders and apply same formatting.
member.dev: This is a presentation object only, does not store any model data.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.BorderCollection.ClearFormatting
member.summary: Removes all borders of an object.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.BorderCollection.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an enumerator object that can be used to iterate over all borders in the collection.

member.overloads: Retrieves a Border object.
member.summary: Retrieves a Border object by border type.

remarks.p: Note that not all borders are present for different document elements. This method throws an exception if you request a border not applicable to the current object.

member.param: A value that specifies the type of the border to retrieve.

member.summary: Retrieves a Border object by index.

member.summary: Gets the number of borders in the collection.

member.summary: Gets or sets the border width in points.

Sets the width of all borders in the collection excluding diagonal borders.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.BorderCollection.LineStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the border style.

Sets the style of all borders in the collection excluding diagonal borders.

member.summary: Gets or sets the border color.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.BorderCollection.DistanceFromText
member.summary: Gets or sets distance of the border from text in points.

remarks.p: Gets the distance from text for the first border.
Sets the distance from text for all borders in the collection excluding diagonal borders.
Has no effect and will be automatically reset to zero for borders of table cells.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.BorderCollection.Shadow
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the border has a shadow.

member.summary: Returns the number of bookmarks in the collection.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.BookmarkCollection.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a bookmark at the specified index.

remarks.p: The index is zero-based.
Negative indexes are allowed and indicate access from the back of the collection. For example -1 means the last item, -2 means the second before last and so on.
If index is greater than or equal to the number of items in the list, this returns a null reference.
If index is negative and its absolute value is greater than the number of items in the list, this returns a null reference.

member.param: An index into the collection.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.BookmarkCollection.Item(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a bookmark by name.

remarks.p: Returns null if the bookmark with the specified name cannot be found.

member.param: Case-insensitive name of the bookmark.

member.remarks: Provides both char and string versions of the same constants. For example: string ControlChar.LineBreak and char ControlChar.LineBreakChar have the same value.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.CellChar
member.summary: End of a table cell or end of a table row character: (char)7 or "\a".

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.TabChar
member.summary: Tab character: (char)9 or "\t".

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.LineFeedChar
member.summary: Line feed character: (char)10 or "\n".

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.LineBreakChar
member.summary: Line break character: (char)11 or "\v".

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.PageBreakChar
member.summary: Page break character: (char)12 or "\f".

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.SectionBreakChar
member.summary: End of section character: (char)12 or "\f".

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.ParagraphBreakChar
member.summary: End of paragraph character: (char)13 or "\r".

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.ColumnBreakChar
member.summary: Enf of column character: (char)14.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.FieldStartChar
member.summary: Start of MS Word field character: (char)19.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.FieldSeparatorChar
member.summary: Field separator character separates field code from field value. Optional in some fields. Value: (char)20.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.FieldEndChar
member.summary: End of MS Word field character: (char)21.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.NonBreakingHyphenChar
member.summary: Nonbreaking Hyphen in Microsoft Word is (char)30.

remarks.p: Nonbreaking Hyphen in Microsoft Word does not correspond to the Unicode character U+2011 non-breaking hyphen but instead represents internal information that tells Microsoft Word to display a hyphen and not to break a line.
Useful info: http://www.cs.tut.fi/~jkorpela/dashes.html#linebreaks.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.OptionalHyphenChar
member.summary: Optional Hyphen in Microsoft Word is (char)31.

remarks.p: Optional Hyphen in Microsoft Word does not correspond to the Unicode character U+00AD soft hyphen. Instead, it inserts internal information that tells Word about a possible hyphenation point.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.ControlChar.SpaceChar

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.Body
member.summary: Represents a container for the main text of a section.

remarks.p: Body can contain Paragraph and Table child nodes.
Body is a section-level node and can only be a child of Section. There can only be one Body in a Section.
A minimal valid Body needs to contain at least one Paragraph.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Body.#ctor(Aspose.Words.DocumentBase)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Body class.

remarks.p: When Body is created, it belongs to the specified document, but is not yet part of the document and ParentNode is null.
To append Body to a Section use Section.InsertAfter or Section.InsertBefore.

member.param: The owner document.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Body.Accept(Aspose.Words.DocumentVisitor)
member.summary: Accepts a visitor.

remarks.p: Enumerates over this node and all of its children. Each node calls a corresponding method on DocumentVisitor.
For more info see the Visitor design pattern.

member.param: The visitor that will visit the nodes.
member.returns: True if all nodes were visited; false if DocumentVisitor stopped the operation before visiting all nodes.
member.remarks: Calls DocumentVisitor.VisitBodyStart, then calls Accept for all child nodes of the section and calls DocumentVisitor.VisitBodyEnd at the end.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Body.EnsureMinimum
member.summary: If the last child is not a paragraph, creates and appends one empty paragraph.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Body.NodeType
member.summary: Returns NodeType.Body.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Body.ParentSection
member.summary: Gets the parent section of this story.

remarks.p: ParentSection is equivalent to (Section)ParentNode.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.Lists.ListTemplate
member.summary: Specifies one of the predefined list formats available in Microsoft Word.

remarks.p: A list template value is used as a parameter into the method.
Aspose.Words list templates correspond to the 21 list templates available in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word 2003.

summary.p: Default bulleted list with 9 levels. Bullet of the first level is a disc, bullet of the second level is a circle, bullet of the third level is a square. Then formatting repeats for the remaining levels.
Each level is indented to the right by 0.25" relative to the previous level.
Corresponds to the 1st bulleted list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
Same as BulletDefault.
Corresponds to the 1st bulleted list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
The bullet of the first level is a circle. The remaining levels are same as in BulletDefault.
Corresponds to the 2nd bulleted list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
The bullet of the first level is a square. The remaining levels are same as in BulletDefault.
Corresponds to the 3rd bulleted list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
The bullet of the first level is a 4-diamond Wingding character. The remaining levels are same as in BulletDefault.
Corresponds to the 5th bulleted list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
The bullet of the first level is an arrow head Wingding character. The remaining levels are same as in BulletDefault.
Corresponds to the 6th bulleted list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
The bullet of the first level is a tick Wingding character. The remaining levels are same as in BulletDefault.
Corresponds to the 7th bulleted list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.

Default numbered list with 9 levels. Arabic numbering (1., 2., 3., ...) for the first level, lowecase letter numbering (a., b., c., ...) for the second level, lowercase roman numbering (i., ii., iii., ...) for the third level. Then formatting repeats for the remaining levels.
Each level is indented to the right by 0.25" relative to the previous level.
Corresponds to the 1st numbered list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
Same as NumberDefault.
Corresponds to the 1st numbered list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
The number of the first level is "1)". The remaining levels are same as in NumberDefault.
Corresponds to the 2nd numbered list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
The number of the first level is "I.". The remaining levels are same as in NumberDefault.
Corresponds to the 3rd numbered list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
The number of the first level is "A.". The remaining levels are same as in NumberDefault.
Corresponds to the 4th numbered list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
The number of the first level is "a)". The remaining levels are same as in NumberDefault.
Corresponds to the 5th numbered list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
The number of the first level is "a.". The remaining levels are same as in NumberDefault.
Corresponds to the 6th numbered list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
The number of the first level is "i.". The remaining levels are same as in NumberDefault.
Corresponds to the 7th numbered list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
An outline list with levels numbered "1), a), i), (1), (a), (i), 1., a., i.".
Corresponds to the 1st outline list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
An outline list with levels are numbered "1., 1.1., 1.1.1, ...".
Corresponds to the 2nd outline list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
An outline lists with various bullets for different levels.
Corresponds to the 3rd outline list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
An outline list with levels linked to Heading styles.
Corresponds to the 4th outline list template in the Bullets and Numbering dialog box in Microsoft Word.
An outline list with levels linked to Heading styles.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.Drawing.WrapType
member.summary: Specifies how text is wrapped around a shape or picture.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Drawing.WrapType.None
member.summary: No text wrapping around the shape. The shape is placed behind or in front of text.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Drawing.WrapType.Inline
member.summary: The shape remains on the same layer as text and treated as a character.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Drawing.WrapType.TopBottom
member.summary: The text stops at the top of the shape and restarts on the line below the shape.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Drawing.WrapType.Square
member.summary: Wraps text around all sides of the square bounding box of the shape.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Drawing.WrapType.Tight
member.summary: Wraps tightly around the edges of the shape, instead of wrapping around the bounding box.

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.Drawing.WrapType.Through
member.summary: Same as Tight, but wraps inside any parts of the shape that are open.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.Drawing.Shape
member.summary: Represents an object in the drawing layer, such as an AutoShape, textbox, freeform, OLE object, ActiveX control, or picture.

remarks.p: Using the class you can create or modify shapes in a Microsoft Word document.

An important property of a shape is its . Shapes of different types can have different capabilities in a Word document. For example, only image and OLE shapes can have images inside them. Most of the shapes can have text, but not all.
Shapes that can have text, can contain and nodes as children.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Drawing.Shape.#ctor(Aspose.Words.DocumentBase)
member.summary: Ctor. Use this internally only.
member.param: The owner document.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Drawing.Shape.#ctor(Aspose.Words.DocumentBase,Aspose.Words.Drawing.ShapeType)
member.summary: Creates a new shape object.

remarks.p: You should specify desired shape properties after you created a shape.

member.param: The owner document.
The type of the shape to create.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Drawing.Shape.Accept(Aspose.Words.DocumentVisitor)
member.summary: Accepts a visitor.

remarks.p: Enumerates over this node and all of its children. Each node calls a corresponding method on DocumentVisitor.
For more info see the Visitor design pattern.

member.param: The visitor that will visit the nodes.
member.returns: True if all nodes were visited; false if DocumentVisitor stopped the operation before visiting all nodes.
member.remarks: Calls , then calls for all child nodes of the shape and calls at the end.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Drawing.Shape.Clone(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a duplicate of the node.

remarks.p: This method serves as a copy constructor for nodes. The cloned node has no parent, but belongs to the same document as the original node.
This method always performs a deep copy of the node. The isCloneChildren parameter specifies whether to perform copy all child nodes as well.

member.param: True to recursively clone the subtree under the specified node; false to clone only the node itself.
member.returns: The cloned node.

member.summary: Returns .

member.summary: Determines whether the closed path of the shape will be filled.

The default value is true.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Drawing.Shape.FillColor
member.summary: Defines the brush color that fills the closed path of the shape.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.Document
member.summary: Represents a Word document.

remarks.p: The Document is a central object in the Aspose.Words library.
To load an existing document in any of the formats, pass a file name or a stream into one of the Document constructors. To create a blank document, call the constructor without parameters.
Use one of the Save method overloads to save the document in any of the formats.
remarks.para: To convert the document into a PDF file (using the new direct rendering engine), use one of the methods. The alternative (legacy) way to convert a document to PDF is to save the document as an XML file in the and pass the XML file to Aspose.Pdf (must be purchased separately).
To convert document page(s) into TIFF, PNG, JPEG, BMP or EMF images, use one of the methods. To draw document pages directly onto a .NET Graphics object use or method.
To print the document, use one of the methods.
remarks.p: is the Aspose.Words's reporting engine that allows to populate reports designed in Microsoft Word with data from various data sources quickly and easily. The data can be from a DataSet, DataTable, DataView, IDataReader or an array of values. MailMerge will go through the records found in the data source and insert them into mail merge fields in the document growing it as necessary.
Document stores document-wide information such as , , , lists and macros. Most of these objects are accessible via the corresponding properties of the Document.

The Document is a root node of a tree that contains all other nodes of the document. The tree is a Composite design pattern and in many ways similar to XmlDocument. The content of the document can be manipulated freely programmatically:

list.item: The nodes of the document can be accessed via typed collections, for example , etc.

The nodes of the document can be selected by their node type using
or using an XPath query with or .
Content nodes can be added or removed from anywhere in the document using , , and other methods provided by the base class .
The formatting attributes of each node can be changed via the properties of that node.

remarks.p: Consider using that simplifies the task of programmatically creating or populating the document tree.
The Document can contain only objects.
In Microsoft Word, a valid document needs to have at least one section.

The document is encrypted and requires a password to open, but you supplied an incorrect password.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Document.#ctor(System.String,Aspose.Words.LoadFormat,System.String)
member.summary: Opens an existing document from a file.

remarks.p: It is recommended that you specify the value and let Aspose.Words detect the file format automatically. If you know the format of the document you are about to load, you can specify the format explicitly and this will reduce the loading time by the overhead associated with auto detecting the format. However, a file can have one extension, but be of a different format (for example a file with the .doc extension can be an .rtf file). If you specify an explicit load format and it will turn out to be wrong, the auto detection will be invoked and a second attempt to load the file will be made.
Use this constructor to open an encrypted Microsoft Word document. You need to know the password to open an encrypted document. If the document is not encrypted, pass null or empty string.

member.param: File name of the document to open.
Specifies the format of the document.
A password to open an encrypted Word document. Pass null or empty string if the document is not encrypted.

The name of the file cannot be null or empty string.

The baseUri parameter is used to resolve relative URIs found in the document to absolute URIs in the following cases:

list.item: When loading an HTML document from a stream and the document contains images with relative URIs and does not have a base URI specified in the BASE HTML element, the baseUri parameter is used to find the images.
When saving in HTML or PDF format, baseUri is used to find images linked in the document using relative paths.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Document.Clone(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a duplicate of the document.

remarks.p: If you need to generate many documents from a single document, just load the document into memory once, clone it and populate the cloned document with your data. This speeds up generation of documents because there is no need to load and parse the document from file every time.

member.param: True to recursively clone the content of the document; false to clone only the document node and document-wide objects such as styles and lists.
member.returns: The cloned document.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Document.Accept(Aspose.Words.DocumentVisitor)
member.summary: Accepts a visitor.

remarks.p: Enumerates over this node and all of its children. Each node calls a corresponding method on DocumentVisitor.
For more info see the Visitor design pattern.

member.param: The visitor that will visit the nodes.
member.returns: True if all nodes were visited; false if DocumentVisitor stopped the operation before visiting all nodes.
member.remarks: Calls DocumentVisitor.VisitDocumentStart, then calls Accept for all child nodes of the document and calls DocumentVisitor.VisitDocumentEnd at the end.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Document.Save(System.Object,Aspose.Words.SaveFormat)
member.summary: Saves the document to a file or to a stream. Use from COM clients (ASP for example).

remarks.p: Use this overload if you want to save the document to a .NET stream or a file from an ASP page or other COM client.
Note that there are several Save overloads and for COM clients this method will be available as Save_4.
allows to specify additional options when saving a file.

example.code:
[ASP]
<%@ LANGUAGE="VBScript" %> <%
Option Explicit
Dim doc Set doc = CreateObject("Aspose.Words.Document")
'Create a .NET memory stream to save the document to. Dim stream Set stream = CreateObject("System.IO.MemoryStream")
'Save the document to the stream. '0 save in DOC format '1 - TXT format '3 - HTML format doc.Save_4 stream, 0
'Specify the document type. Response.ContentType = "application/msword" 'Other options: 'Response.ContentType = "text/plain" 'Response.ContentType = "text/html"
'Specify how the document is sent to the browser. Response.AddHeader "content-disposition","attachment; filename=MyDocument.doc" 'Another option could be: 'Response.AddHeader("content-disposition","inline; filename=MyDocument.doc");
'Get data bytes from the stream and send it to the response. Dim bytes bytes = stream.ToArray() Response.BinaryWrite(bytes)
Response.End %>

member.param: Can be a file name or a .
The format in which to save the document.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Document.Protect(Aspose.Words.ProtectionType)
member.overloads: Protects the document from changes.
member.summary: Protects the document from changes without changing the existing password or assigns a random password.

remarks.p: When a document is protected, the user can make only limited changes, such as adding annotations, making revisions, or completing a form.
When you protect a document, and the document already has a protection password, the existing protection password is not changed.

When you protect a document, and the document does not have a protection password, this method assigns a random password that makes it impossible to unprotect the document in Microsoft Word, but you still can unprotect the document in Aspose.Words as it does not require a password when unprotecting.

member.param: Specifies the protection type for the document.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Document.Protect(Aspose.Words.ProtectionType,System.String)
member.summary: Protects the document from changes and optionally sets a protection password.

remarks.p: When a document is protected, the user can make only limited changes, such as adding annotations, making revisions, or completing a form.
remarks.para: Note that document protection is different from write protection. Write protection is specified using the .

member.param: Specifies the protection type for the document.
The password to protect the document with. Specify null or empty string if you want to protect the document without a password.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Document.Unprotect
member.summary: Removes protection from the document.

remarks.para: This method unprotects the document even if it has a protection password.
Note that document protection is different from write protection. Write protection is specified using the .

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Document.UpdateWordCount
member.summary: Updates word count properties of the document.

remarks.p: UpdateWordCount recalculates and updates Characters, Words and Paragraphs properties in the collection of the Document.
Note that UpdateWordCount does not update number of lines and pages properties.
When you use an evaluation version, the evaluation watermark will also be included in the word count.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Document.UpdateTableLayout
member.summary: Updates widths of cells and tables according to their preferred widths and content.

remarks.p: You don't normally need to call this method as cell and table widths are maintained automatically. You might need to call this method before exporting to PDF, only in rare cases where a table appear incorrectly laid out in PDF output.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Document.RemoveMacros
member.summary: Removes all macros (the VBA project) from the document.

remarks.p: By removing all macros from a document you can ensure the document contains no macro viruses.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Document.UpdateFields
member.summary: Updates the values of document fields. Not all field types are updated.

remarks.p: At the moment updates the results of DOCPROPERTY and DOCVARIABLE fields only. You can update fields in a specific part of the document using .

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Document.JoinRunsWithSameFormatting
member.summary: Joins runs with same formatting in all paragraphs of the document.

remarks.p: This is an optimization method. Some documents contain adjacent runs with same formatting. Usually this occurs if a document was intensively edited manually. You can reduce the document size and speed up further processing by joining these runs.

The operation checks every node in the document for adjacent nodes having identical properties. It ignores unique identifiers used to track editing sessions of run creation and modification. First run in every joining sequence accumulates all text. Remaining runs are deleted from the document.

member.returns: Number of joins performed. When N adjacent runs are being joined they count as N - 1 joins.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Document.ExpandTableStylesToDirectFormatting
member.summary: Converts formatting specified in table styles into direct formatting on tables in the document.

remarks.para: This method exists because this version of Aspose.Words provides only limited support for table styles (see below). This method might be useful when you load a DOCX or WordprocessingML document that contains tables formatted with table styles and you need to query formatting of tables, cells, paragraphs or text.

list.listheader: This version of Aspose.Words provides limited support for table styles as follows:
list.item: Table styles defined in DOCX or WordprocessingML documents are preserved as table styles when saving the document as DOCX or WordprocessingML.
Table styles defined in DOCX or WordprocessingML documents are automatically converted to direct formatting on tables when saving the document into any other format, rendering or printing.
Table styles defined in DOC documents are preserved as table styles when saving the document as DOC only.

remarks.para: This property allows to control whether the document will be saved as a template when writing to a stream. If you are writing to a file, then the file name extension will control whether the document is saved as a template (e.g. .DOC vs .DOT and .DOCX vs .DOTX).
