member.name: T:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge
member.summary: Represents the mail merge functionality.

remarks.p: For mail merge operation to work, the document should contain Word MERGEFIELD and optionally NEXT fields. During mail merge operation, merge fields in the document are replaced with values from your data source.
There are two distinct ways to use mail merge: with mail merge regions and without.

The simplest mail merge is without regions and it is very similar to how mail merge works in Word. Use Execute methods to merge information from some data source such as DataTable, DataView, IDataReader or an array of objects into your document. The MailMerge object processes all records of the data source and copies and appends content of the whole document for each record.
Note that when MailMerge object encounters a NEXT field, it selects next record in the data source and continues merging without copying any content.
Use ExecuteWithRegions methods to merge information into a document with mail merge regions defined. You can use DataSet, DataTable, DataView or IDataReader as data sources for this operation.
You need to use mail merge regions if you want to dynamically grow portions inside the document. Without mail merge regions whole document will be repeated for every record of the data source.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.Execute(Aspose.Words.Reporting.IMailMergeDataSource)
member.summary: Performs a mail merge from a custom data source.

remarks.p: Use this method to fill mail merge fields in the document with values from any data source such as a list or hashtable or objects. You need to write your own class that implements the interface.

member.param: An object that implements the custom mail merge data source interface.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.Execute(System.String[],System.Object[])
member.overloads: Performs a mail merge operation.
member.summary: Performs a mail merge operation for a single record.

remarks.p: Use this method to fill mail merge fields in the document with values from an array of objects.
This method merges data for one record only. The array of field names and the array of values represent the data of a single record.
This method does not use mail merge regions.

member.param: Array of merge field names. Field names are not case sensitive. If a field name that is not found in the document is encountered, it is ignored.
Array of values to be inserted into the merge fields. Number of elements in this array must be the same as the number of elements in fieldNames.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.Execute(System.Data.DataTable)
member.summary: Performs mail merge from a DataTable into the document.

remarks.p: Use this method to fill mail merge fields in the document with values from a DataTable.
All records from the table are merged into the document.
You can use NEXT field in the Word document to cause MailMerge object to select next record from the DataTable and continue merging. This can be used when creating documents such as mailing labels.

When MailMerge object reaches end of the main document and there are still more rows in the DataTable, it copies entire content of the main document and appends it to the end of the destination document using a section break as a separator.

member.param: Table that contains data to be inserted into mail merge fields. Field names are not case sensitive. If a field name that is not found in the document is encountered, it is ignored.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.ExecuteADO(System.Object)
member.summary: Performs mail merge from an ADO Recordset object into the document.

remarks.p: This method is useful when you intend to use Aspose.Words classes as COM objects from unmanaged code such as an application built using ASP or Visual Basic 6.0.
For more information see description of MailMerge.Execute(DataTable).

example.code:
[VBScript]
Dim RS Set RS = CreateObject("ADODB.Recordset") RS.Open _ "SELECT TOP 50 * FROM Customers ORDER BY Country, CompanyName", _ "Provider=Microsoft.Jet.OLEDB.4.0;Data Source=Northwind.mdb"
Dim License Set License = CreateObject("Aspose.Words.License") License.SetLicense "C:\MyPath\MyLicense.lic"
Dim Helper Set Helper = CreateObject("Aspose.Words.ComHelper") Dim Doc Set Doc = Helper.Open("CustomerLabels.doc")
Doc.MailMerge.ExecuteADO RS Doc.Save "C:\MyPath\CustomerLabels Out VBScript.doc"

member.param: ADO Recordset or Record object.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.Execute(System.Data.IDataReader)
member.summary: Performs mail merge from IDataReader into the document.

remarks.p: You can pass SqlDataReader or OleDbDataReader object into this method as a parameter because they both implemented IDataReader interface.
Note this method does not use mail merge regions and for multiple records the document will grow by repeating the whole document.

member.param: Data source for the mail merge operation.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.Execute(System.Data.DataView)
member.summary: Performs mail merge from a DataView into the document.

remarks.p: This method is useful if you retrieve data into a DataTable but then need to apply a filter or sort before the mail merge.
Note this method does not use mail merge regions and for multiple records the document will grow by repeating the whole document.

member.param: Data source for the mail merge operation.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.Execute(System.Data.DataRow)
member.summary: Performs mail merge from a DataRow into the document.

remarks.p: Use this method to fill mail merge fields in the document with values from a DataRow.

member.param: Row that contains data to be inserted into mail merge fields. Field names are not case sensitive. If a field name that is not found in the document is encountered, it is ignored.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.ExecuteWithRegions(Aspose.Words.Reporting.IMailMergeDataSource)
member.summary: Performs a mail merge from a custom data source with mail merge regions.

remarks.p: Use this method to fill mail merge fields in the document with values from any data source such as a list or hashtable or objects. You need to write your own class that implements the interface.

member.param: An object that implements the custom mail merge data source interface.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.ExecuteWithRegions(System.Data.DataSet)
member.overloads: Performs a mail merge operation into a document with mail merge regions.
member.summary: Performs mail merge from a DataSet into a document with mail merge regions.

remarks.p: Use this method to perform mail merge from one or more tables into repeatable mail merge regions in the document. The mail merge regions inside the document will dynamically grow to accomodate records in the corresponding tables.
Every table in the DataSet must have a name.
The document must have mail merge regions defined with names that refer to the tables in the DataSet.
To specify a mail merge region in the document you need to insert two mail merge fields to mark beginning and end of the mail merge region.
All document content that is included inside a mail merge region will be automatically repeated for every record in the DataTable.
To mark beginning of a mail merge region insert a MERGEFIELD with name TableStart:MyTable, where MyTable corresponds to one of the table names in your DataSet.
To mark the end of the mail merge region insert another MERGEFIELD with name TableEnd:MyTable.
To insert a MERGEFIELD in Word use Insert/Field command and select MergeField then type the name of the field.
Note that TableStart and TableEnd fields must be inside the same section in your document.
If used inside a table, TableStart and TableEnd must be inside the same row in the table.
Note that mail merge regions cannot be nested inside each other and they should be well formed (there is always a pair of matching TableStart and TableEnd with the same table name).

member.param: DataSet that contains data to be inserted into mail merge fields.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.ExecuteWithRegions(System.Data.DataTable)
member.summary: Performs mail merge from a DataTable into the document with mail merge regions.

remarks.p: The document must have a mail merge region defined with name that matches DataTable.TableName.
If there are other mail merge regions defined in the document they are left intact. This allows to perform several mail merge operations.

member.param: Data source for the mail merge operation. The table must have its TableName property set.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.ExecuteWithRegionsADO(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Performs mail merge from an ADO Recordset object into the document with mail merge regions.

remarks.p: This method is useful when you intend to use Aspose.Words classes as COM objects from unmanaged code such as an application built using ASP or Visual Basic 6.0.
For more information see description of MailMerge.ExecuteWithRegions(DataTable).

example.code:
[VBScript]
Dim RS Set RS = CreateObject("ADODB.Recordset") RS.Open _ "SELECT * FROM AsposeWordOrderDetails WHERE OrderId = 10444 ORDER BY ProductID", _ "Provider=Microsoft.Jet.OLEDB.4.0;Data Source=Northwind.mdb"
Dim Helper Set Helper = CreateObject("Aspose.Words.ComHelper")
Dim Doc Set Doc = Helper.Open("Invoice.doc")
Doc.MailMerge.ExecuteWithRegionsADO RS, "OrderDetails" Doc.Save "Invoice Out VBScript.doc"

member.param: ADO Recordset or Record object.
Name of the mail merge region in the document to populate.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.ExecuteWithRegions(System.Data.DataView)
member.summary: Performs mail merge from a DataView into the document with mail merge regions.

remarks.p: This method is useful if you retrieve data into a DataTable but then need to apply a filter or sort before the mail merge.
The document must have a mail merge region defined with name that matches DataView.Table.TableName.
If there are other mail merge regions defined in the document they are left intact. This allows to perform several mail merge operations.

member.param: Data source for the mail merge operation. The source table of the DataView must have its TableName property set.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.ExecuteWithRegions(System.Data.IDataReader,System.String)
member.summary: Performs mail merge from IDataReader into the document with mail merge regions.

remarks.p: You can pass SqlDataReader or OleDbDataReader object into this method as a parameter because they both implemented IDataReader interface.

member.param: Source of the data records for mail merge such as OleDbDataReader or SqlDataReader.
Name of the mail merge region in the document to populate.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.GetFieldNames
member.summary: Returns a collection of mail merge field names available in the document.

remarks.p: Returns full merge field names including optional prefix. Does not eliminate duplicate field names.
A new string[] array is created on every call.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.DeleteFields
member.summary: Removes mail merge related fields from the document.

remarks.p: This method removes MERGEFIELD and NEXT fields from the document.
This method could be useful if your mail merge operation does not always need to populate all fields in the document. Use this method to remove all remaining mail merge fields.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.RemoveEmptyParagraphs
member.summary: Specifies whether paragraphs that contained mail merge fields with no data should be removed from the document.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.UseNonMergeFields
member.summary: When true, specifies that in addition to MERGEFIELD fields, mail merge is performed into some other types of fields.

remarks.p: Normally, mail merge is only performed into MERGEFIELD fields, but several customers had their reporting built using other fields and had many documents created this way. To simplify migration (and because this approach was independetly used by several customers) the ability to mail merge into other fields was introduced.
When UseNonMergeFields is set to true, mail merge will be performed into the following fields:
MERGEFIELD FieldName
MACROBUTTON NOMACRO FieldName
IF 0 = 0 "{FieldName}" ""

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.MappedDataFields
member.summary: Returns a collection that represents mapped data fields for the mail merge operation.

remarks.p: Mapped data fields allow to automatically map between names of fields in your data source and names of mail merge fields in the document.

member.name: E:Aspose.Words.Reporting.MailMerge.MergeImageField

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.LineStyle
member.summary: Specifies line style of a .

member.name: F:Aspose.Words.LineStyle.None
member.dev:
In MS Word binary format LineStyle.None means no border for all objects, except table cells.
For table cells LineStyle.None means inherit from the default table border.
Apparently this looks like a very bad hack made by someone at MS and I work around it by making LineStyle.None to mean "no border" for any object in the model including table cells. The translation is performed in the binary cell reader/writer.
I also use a single approach to indicate that a border is inherited. At first the border attribute is simply missing, but if a use requests it, a Border object is instantiated in "inherited" mode.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.ParagraphCollection
member.summary: Provides typed access to a collection of nodes.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.ParagraphCollection.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves a Paragraph at the given index.

remarks.p: The index is zero-based.
Negative indexes are allowed and indicate access from the back of the collection. For example -1 means the last item, -2 means the second before last and so on.
If index is greater than or equal to the number of items in the list, this returns a null reference.
If index is negative and its absolute value is greater than the number of items in the list, this returns a null reference.

member.param: An index into the collection.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.Paragraph
member.summary: Represents a paragraph of text.

remarks.p: is a block-level node and can be a child of classes derived from or .
can contain any number of inline-level nodes and bookmarks.
The complete list of child nodes that can occur inside a paragraph consists of , , , , , , , , , , , , .

A valid paragraph in Microsoft Word always ends with a paragraph break character and a minimal valid paragraph consists just of a paragraph break. The Paragraph class automatically appends the appropriate paragraph break character at the end and this character is not part of the child nodes of the Paragraph, therefore a Paragraph can be empty.

Do not include the end of paragraph ControlChar.ParagraphBreak or end of cell ControlChar.Cell characters inside the text of the paragraph as it might make the paragraph invalid when the document is opened in Microsoft Word.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Paragraph.#ctor(Aspose.Words.DocumentBase)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Paragraph class.

remarks.p: When Paragraph is created, it belongs to the specified document, but is not yet part of the document and ParentNode is null.
To append Paragraph to the document use InsertAfter or InsertBefore on the story where you want the paragraph inserted.

member.param: The owner document.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Paragraph.Clone(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a duplicate of the node.

remarks.p: This method serves as a copy constructor for nodes. The cloned node has no parent, but belongs to the same document as the original node.
This method always performs a deep copy of the node. The isCloneChildren parameter specifies whether to perform copy all child nodes as well.

member.param: True to recursively clone the subtree under the specified node; false to clone only the node itself.
member.returns: The cloned node.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Paragraph.Accept(Aspose.Words.DocumentVisitor)
member.summary: Accepts a visitor.

remarks.p: Enumerates over this node and all of its children. Each node calls a corresponding method on DocumentVisitor.
For more info see the Visitor design pattern.

member.param: The visitor that will visit the nodes.
member.returns: True if all nodes were visited; false if DocumentVisitor stopped the operation before visiting all nodes.
member.remarks: Calls DocumentVisitor.VisitParagraphStart, then calls Accept for all child nodes of the paragraph and calls DocumentVisitor.VisitParagraphEnd at the end.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Paragraph.GetText
member.summary: Gets the text of this paragraph including the end of paragraph character.

remarks.p: The text of all child nodes is concatenated and the end of paragraph character is appended as follows:

list.item: If the paragraph is the last paragraph of , then ControlChar.SectionBreak (\x000c) is appended.
If the paragraph is the last paragraph of , then ControlChar.Cell (\x0007) is appended.
For all other paragraphs ControlChar.ParagraphBreak (\r) is appended.

remarks.p: The returned string includes all control and special characters as described in .

member.dev: Not sure where lvlElt.tplc is stored in the DOC file. Sounds like it is a template code for individual list levels. VA: All tplc are stored in a separate table in a document. They can be seen in binary going one after another. Not sure how to locate them in the document structure though.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Lists.ListLevel.StartAt
member.summary: Returns or sets the starting number for this list level.

remarks.p: Default value is 1.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Lists.ListLevel.NumberStyle
member.summary: Returns or sets the number style for this list level.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Lists.ListLevel.NumberFormat
member.summary: Returns or sets the number format for the list level.

remarks.p: Among normal text characters, the string can contain placeholder characters \x0000 to \x0008 representing the numbers from the corresponding list levels.

For example, the string "\x0000.\x0001)" will generate a list label that looks something like "1.5)". The number "1" is the current number from the 1st list level, the number "5" is the current number from the 2nd list level.
Null is not allowed, but an empty string meaning no number is valid.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.Range
member.summary: Represents a contiguous area in a document.

remarks.p: The document is represented by a tree of nodes and the nodes provide operations to work with the tree, but some operations are easier to perform if the document is treated as a contiguous sequence of text.

Range is a "facade" interface that provide methods that treat the document or portions of the document as "flat" text regardless of the fact that the document nodes are stored in a tree-like object model.
Range does not contain any text or nodes, it is merely a view or "window" over a fragment of a document.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Range.Delete
member.summary: Deletes all characters of the range.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Range.Replace(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.overloads: Replaces all occurrences of a specified string in this range, with another string.
member.summary: Replaces all occurrences of a specified string with another string.

remarks.p: An exception is thrown if a captured or replacement string contain one or more special characters: paragraph break, cell break, section break, field start, field separator, field end, inline picture, drawing object, footnote.

member.param: A string to be replaced.
A string to replace all occurrences of oldValue.
True indicates case-sensitive comparison, false indicates case-insensitive comparision.
True indicates the oldValue must be a standalone word.
member.returns: The number of replacements made.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Range.Replace(System.Text.RegularExpressions.Regex,System.String)
member.summary: Replaces all occurrences of a character pattern specified by a regular expression with another string.

remarks.p: Replaces the whole match captured by the regular expression.

An exception is thrown if a captured or replacement string contain one or more special characters: paragraph break, cell break, section break, field start, field separator, field end, inline picture, drawing object, footnote.

member.param: A regular expression pattern used to find matches.
A string to replace all occurrences of oldValue.
member.returns: The number of replacements made.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.Range.Replace(System.Text.RegularExpressions.Regex,Aspose.Words.ReplaceEvaluator,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Finds all occurrences of a character pattern specified by a regular expression and calls a user defined replace evaluator method.

remarks.p: An exception is thrown if a captured or replacement string contain one or more special characters: paragraph break, cell break, section break, field start, field separator, field end, inline picture, drawing object, footnote.

member.param: A regular expression pattern used to find matches.
The user-defined method which evaluates replacement at each step.
True to replace from the beginning of the range to the end.
member.returns: The number of replacements made.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.HeaderFooter
member.summary: Represents a container for the header or footer text of a section.

remarks.p: HeaderFooter can contain Paragraph and Table child nodes.
HeaderFooter is a section-level node and can only be a child of Section. There can only be one HeaderFooter or each in a Section.

If Section does not have a HeaderFooter of a specific type or the HeaderFooter has no child nodes, this header/footer is considered linked to the header/footer of the same type of the previous section in Microsoft Word.
When HeaderFooter contains at least one one Paragraph, it is no longer considered linked to previous in Microsoft Word.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.HeaderFooter.#ctor(Aspose.Words.DocumentBase,Aspose.Words.HeaderFooterType)
member.summary: Creates a new header or footer of the specified type.

remarks.p: When HeaderFooter is created, it belongs to the specified document, but is not yet part of the document and ParentNode is null.
To append HederFooter to a Section use Section.InsertAfter, Section.InsertBefore, HeadersFooters.Add or HeadersFooters.Insert.

member.param: The owner document.
A value that specifies the type of the header or footer.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.HeaderFooter.Accept(Aspose.Words.DocumentVisitor)
member.summary: Accepts a visitor.

remarks.p: Enumerates over this node and all of its children. Each node calls a corresponding method on DocumentVisitor.
For more info see the Visitor design pattern.

member.param: The visitor that will visit the nodes.
member.returns: True if all nodes were visited; false if DocumentVisitor stopped the operation before visiting all nodes.
member.remarks: Calls DocumentVisitor.VisitHeaderFooterStart, then calls Accept for all child nodes of the section and calls DocumentVisitor.VisitHeaderFooterEnd at the end.

member.summary: Represents a Word field separator that separates the field code from the field result.

remarks.p: is an inline-level node and represented by the control character in the document.
can only be a child of .

A complete field in a Microsoft Word document is a complex structure consisting of a field start character, field code, field separator character, field result and field end character. Some fields only have field start, field code and field end.
To easily insert a new field into a document, use the method.

member.summary: Gets or sets distance of the border from text or from the page edge in points.
member.remarks: Has no effect and will be automatically reset to zero for borders of table cells.

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.Border.Shadow
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the border has a shadow.

remarks.p: In Microsoft Word, for a border to have a shadow, the borders on all four sides (left, top, right and bottom) should be of the same type, width, color and all should have the Shadow property set to true.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.TabStop
member.summary: Represents a single custom tab stop. The TabStop object is a member of the collection.

remarks.p: Normally, a tab stop specifies a position where a tab stop exists. But because tab stops can be inherited from parent styles, it might be needed for the child object to define explicitly that there is no tab stop at a given position. To clear an inherited tab stop at a given position, create a TabStop object and set to TabAlignment.Clear.
Fore more information see .

member.name: P:Aspose.Words.RunCollection.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves a Run at the given index.

remarks.p: The index is zero-based.
Negative indexes are allowed and indicate access from the back of the collection. For example -1 means the last item, -2 means the second before last and so on.
If index is greater than or equal to the number of items in the list, this returns a null reference.
If index is negative and its absolute value is greater than the number of items in the list, this returns a null reference.

member.param: An index into the collection.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.BuildingBlocks.BuildingBlock.Accept(Aspose.Words.DocumentVisitor)
member.summary: Accepts a visitor.

remarks.p: Enumerates over this node and all of its children. Each node calls a corresponding method on DocumentVisitor.
For more info see the Visitor design pattern.

member.param: The visitor that will visit the nodes.
member.returns: True if all nodes were visited; false if DocumentVisitor stopped the operation before visiting all nodes.

remarks.para: Calls , then calls for all child nodes of this building block, then calls .
Note: A building block node and its children are not visited when you execute a Visitor over a . If you want to execute a Visitor over a building block, you need to execute the visitor over or call .

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.BuildingBlocks.BuildingBlock.Clone(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a duplicate of the node.

remarks.p: This method serves as a copy constructor for nodes. The cloned node has no parent, but belongs to the same document as the original node.
This method always performs a deep copy of the node. The isCloneChildren parameter specifies whether to perform copy all child nodes as well.

member.param: True to recursively clone the subtree under the specified node; false to clone only the node itself.
member.returns: The cloned node.

member.name: T:Aspose.Words.License
member.summary: Provides methods to license the component.
member.example:
In this example, an attempt will be made to find a license file named MyLicense.lic in the folder that contains
the component, in the folder that contains the calling assembly, in the folder of the entry assembly and then in the embedded resources of the calling assembly.
[C#]
License license = new License(); license.SetLicense("MyLicense.lic");
[Visual Basic]
Dim license As license = New license License.SetLicense("MyLicense.lic")

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.License.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of this class.
member.example:
In this example, an attempt will be made to find a license file named MyLicense.lic in the folder that contains
the component, in the folder that contains the calling assembly, in the folder of the entry assembly and then in the embedded resources of the calling assembly.
[C#]
License license = new License(); license.SetLicense("MyLicense.lic");
[Visual Basic]
Dim license As license = New license License.SetLicense("MyLicense.lic")

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.License.SetLicense(System.String)
member.summary: Licenses the component.

remarks.p: Tries to find the license in the following locations:
1. Explicit path.
2. The folder of the component assembly.
3. The folder of the client's calling assembly.
4. The folder of the entry assembly.
5. An embedded resource in the client's calling assembly.
Note:On the .NET Compact Framework, tries to find the license only in these locations:
1. Explicit path.
2. An embedded resource in the client's calling assembly.

member.example:
In this example, an attempt will be made to find a license file named MyLicense.lic in the folder that contains
the component, in the folder that contains the calling assembly, in the folder of the entry assembly and then in the embedded resources of the calling assembly.
[C#]
License license = new License(); license.SetLicense("MyLicense.lic");
[Visual Basic]
Dim license As License = New License license.SetLicense("MyLicense.lic") Can be a full or short file name or name of an embedded resource. Use an empty string to switch to evaluation mode.

member.name: M:Aspose.Words.License.SetLicense(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Licenses the component.
member.param: A stream that contains the license.

remarks.p: Use this method to load a license from a stream.
